entry.content:
9-2-2017 Sheep Gap & Deep Creek Fires Update

Incident: Sheep Gap Wildfire
Released: 1:45 hrs. ago

Sheep Creek and Deep Creek Fires Update
September 2, 2017, 7 A.M. Phone: 406-826-4345 or 406-529-5475 Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5558/

Contact: John Hamilton

What: Sheep Gap and Deep Creek Fires Update
Location: Fire is approximately 9 miles west of Plains, Plains-Thompson Falls Ranger District (T 20 North R 27 W Section 7), Deep Creek Fire is approximately 12 miles northwest of Thompson Falls, (T 23 North R 30 W Section 14)
Size: Sheep Gap 2,242 acres, Deep Creek 533 acres
Containment: 0
Cause: Started by lightning Aug. 29 (Sheep Gap), Aug. 30 (Deep Creek)

The Sheep Gap and Deep Creeks Fires: The Sheep Gap and Deep Creek fires were started by lightning earlier this week and are currently being managed jointly under a local incident management team. Pre-evacuation notices have been issued to residents near both fires, for the River Road West and West Fork Swamp areas on the Sheep Gap fire, and for the Blue Slide road area for the Deep Creek fire. The primary objectives for both fires is to first secure identified resources of value and structures in the vicinity of each incident while attempting to contain both. Contingency lines are being constructed on the Sheep Gap fire in case the fire moves towards the east or north where structures are located. Helicopters with buckets, heavy air tanker retardant and single engine air tanker retardant planes continue to be utilized to help contain fire spread. Continuing hot and dry weather, with temperatures forecast to be well into the 90s for the next several days, are another factor affecting fire behavior on all fires burning in the area.

Resources: Resources assigned to the incidents include 51 personnel, several engines and a structure assessment group on the Sheep Gap fire, and two 20-person crews on the Deep Creek fire. Structure assessment and pre-evacuation planning is also ongoing on the Deep Creek fire.
Both fires will continue to utilize helicopters with buckets and retardant planes as available and needed.

Structures: Both fires have structures and dwellings below the incidents along roads, and pre- evacuation warnings have been issued to those residents determined to be possibly affected. Homeowners have been advised to keep informed on current fire conditions and to be prepared as possible in the event that evacuations are implemented by the Sanders County Sheriff’s office.

Hazards: Steep, rocky terrain on both fires and access to both is problematic. Very dry forest fuels and continuing hot and dry weather are complicating factors. The hunting season for upland game birds and archery starts today in Montana, meaning more people will be out and the risk of new fire starts will increase.

If you fly, we can’t! The use of unmanned aircraft (drones) is illegal near forest fires and can force the grounding of firefighting aircraft, jeopardize firefighter and pilot safety and impede successful suppression.

Closures: Roads and trails in both fire areas have been closed. Please see those area closure orders for more information on specific roads and trails. Please access Inciweb at https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/closures/5558/ for all roads and trails affected.

F17-077-LOLO-D5

LOLO NATIONAL FOREST

24 Fort Missoula Road

Missoula, Montana 59804-7297

FOREST SUPERVISOR’S ORDER

Pursuant to Title 36 Code of Federal Regulations 261.50 (a & b), the following acts are prohibited as described below within the Plains/Thompson Falls Ranger District of the Lolo National Forest. These restrictions are in addition to those enumerated in Subpart A, Part 261, Title 36, Code of Federal Regulations, and become effective upon signing and will remain in effect until rescinded.

36 CFR – Special Closures

It is prohibited to go into or be upon the area (36 CFR 261.53(e)).

The closure cited in this order is to protect the public from potential harm from wildfires and firefighting operations associated with the Deep Creek Fire.

Description of Closed Areas:

This area closure closes the area as described below and shown on the ATTACHED MAP.

All of sections 3 – 8, and parts of sections 1, 2, 9 – 11, & 16 – 19, T. 22 N., R. 29 W.

Part of section 1, T. 22 N., R. 30 W.

All of sections and Protracted Blocks PB37, PB38, 8, 16, 17, PB39, PB40, 20 – 23, 27 – 29, PB41, PB42, PB43, PB44, & PB45, and parts of sections and Protracted Blocks 5, 9, 10, 14, 15, 24, 25, 26, PB46, PB47, T. 23 N., R. 29 W.

All of sections 1, 11 – 15, & 23 – 25, and parts of sections 2, 9, 10, 22, 26, 36, T. 23 N., R. 30 W.

Parts of sections and Protracted Blocks 30, PB45, & 32, T. 24 N., R. 29 W.

All of Protracted Block PB52 and part of section 25 and part of Protracted Block PB51, T. 24 N., R. 30 W

36 CFR – National Forest System Roads

Being on the road. 36 CFR 261.54(e). It is prohibited to be on the road.

The closure cited in this order is to protect the public from potential harm from wildfires and firefighting operations associated with the Deep Creek Fire.

Description of Closed Road:

Including all road encompassed by the area closure. See description of area closure above. See attached map.

36 CFR – National Forest System Trails

Being on the trail. 36 CFR 261.55(a). It is prohibited to be on the trail.

The closure cited in this order is to protect the public from potential harm from wildfires and firefighting operations associated with the Deep Creek Fire.

Description of Trails:

Including all trails encompassed by the area closure. See description of area closure above. See attached map.

Exemptions:

Pursuant to 36 CFR 261.50(e), the following persons are exempt from this order:

1. Persons with a permit issued by a forest officer specifically authorizing the otherwise prohibited act or omission. 2. Any Federal, State, or local officer, or member of an organized rescue or firefighting force in the performance of an official duty.

Signed in Missoula, Montana, this 1st day of September, 2017.

/s/ Timothy Garcia

Timothy Garcia

Forest Supervisor

Lolo National Forest

Penalty: Violation of these prohibitions is punishable by a fine of not more than $5000 for and individual or $10,000 for an organization, or imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both (16 USC 551 and 18 USC 3559 and 3571).

Notification: A copy of this order shall be posted as prescribed in 36 CFR 261.51.

09-01-2017_Sheep Gap Fire Update

Incident: Sheep Gap Wildfire
Released: 24 hrs. ago

September 1, 2017, 7 A.M.

Contact: John HamiltonPhone: 406-826-4345 or 406-529-5475 Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5558/

What: Sheep Gap and Deep Creek Fire Update Location: Sheep Gap fire is approximately 9 miles west of Plains, Plains-Thompson Falls Ranger District (T 20 North R 27 W Section 7); Deep Creek fire is approximately 12 miles northwest of Thompson Falls (T 23 North R 30 W Section 14) Size: Approximately 1,637 acres Containment: 0 Cause: Started by lightning August 29 The Sheep Gap and Deep Creek fires: Both fires were started by lightning earlier this week. A Type 3 organization was assigned management of the Deep Creek fire as well as the Sheep Gap fire as of this morning, September 1. The primary initial attack priorities on both fast-growing incidents is to first secure identified high-value resources while attempting to control these fires. Helicopters with buckets, heavy air tankers and single engine air tankers were utilized when available throughout the work cycle. High winds associated with forecast red flag weather warnings curtailed these activities in the afternoon. Contingency lines were being constructed at strategic locations ahead of the Sheep Gap fire. Resources: Heavy air tankers and helicopters were also instrumental in moderating spread on the Deep Creek fire, which has no road access. Three engines were being utilized on the Sheep Gap fire. A 20-person crew is on the Deep Creek fire and approximately 50 personnel are assigned to the Sheep Gap fire. Structures: Both fires have structures and dwellings well below the incidents along roads, and pre-evacuation warnings have been issued to those residents. Homeowners that have been contacted have a clearly identifiable purple ribbon attached to those residences to aid in the rapid identification should evacuation procedures be implemented. A structure assessment specialist is presently going door-to-door through the area to ensure that people are aware of the situation. Hazards: Steep, rocky terrain and access to both fires is problematic. Very dry forest fuels and continuing hot and dry weather are complicating factors. The rugged terrain is very challenging for on-the-ground forces. If you fly, we can’t! The use of unmanned aircraft (drones) is illegal near forest fires and can force the grounding of firefighting aircraft, jeopardize firefighter and pilot safety and impede successful suppression. Please, don’t be the person that helps this fire escape.

Closures: Road Nos. 7583 and 7589, and Road No. 217 after the junction with 7589 are closed. Trails 385 (Sacajawea Peak), 398 (Dee Creek) and 1400 (West Fork of Swamp Creek) are also closed. See Inciweb for additional area closure information: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/closures/5558/. Area closures for public and firefighter safety will be established today around both of these fires.

08-31-2017_Sheep Gap Fire Update

Incident: Sheep Gap Wildfire
Released: 1 day ago


August 31, 2017, 7 P.M.

Contact: John Hamilton Phone: 406-826-4345 or 406-529-5475 Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5558/

What: Sheep Gap Fire Update Location: Fire is approximately 9 miles west of Plains, Plains-Thompson Falls Ranger District (T 20 North R 27 W Section 7) Size: Approximately 1000 acres Containment: 0 Cause: Started by lightning at approximately 5 p.m., Aug. 29 The Sheep Gap Fire: Fire was started by lightning on the evening of Aug. 29 and quickly grew to over 200 acres that night. By evening Aug 30, the fire has grown to an estimated 1000 acres. The Forest Service will conduct an infrared detection flight overnight to determine the new size and perimeter of the fire. Today firefighters reinforced fire line on the northern edge to prevent movement toward structures and other resources of value. Air tankers laid down a line of fire retardant along the south edge of Road 7581 to increase the road’s effectiveness as a fireline. Firefighters using helicopter bucket drops successfully knocked down a spot fire that had become established north of the road. Resources: Heavy air tankers and helicopters were instrumental in moderating spread of the fire to allow work on contingency lines between the fire and homes to the north. Excavators worked to clear roads for use as firelines. More personnel will be assigned to the fire as they are released from other fires in the area. Firefighting resources, both equipment and people, are being moved among separate fires to protect the highest values at risk. Structures: This fire does not directly threaten structures currently, but pre-evacuation notices have been issued to residents along River Road West. Residents in areas under warning notice should be prepared to evacuate with very little additional notice. Hazards: Steep, rocky terrain. Access to much of the fire area is difficult. The forest fuels feeding the fire are at near-record dryness, and low humidity and wind have made all Montana fires extremely dangerous and rapidly moving. If you fly, we can’t! The use of unmanned aircraft (drones) is illegal near forest fires and can force the grounding of firefighting aircraft, jeopardize firefighter and pilot safety and impede successful suppression. Please, don’t be the person that helps this fire escape. Closures: Road Nos. 7583 and 7589, and Road No. 217 after the junction with 7589 are closed. Trails 385 (Sacajawea Peak), 398 (Dee Creek) and 1400 (West Fork of Swamp Creek) are also closed. See Inciweb for additional area closure information: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/closures/5558/
